turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Emily's going south next week with the child.  As far as anybody's to know, it's a holiday.  When they get back -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Brad, you are drunk.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Sure I am.  She wants full custody of the child no matter what happens. If you won't agree to that, she'll apply for a divorce regardless of the President's wishes.  I can't tell her she's wrong, because she isn't wrong -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Why is she leaving me?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: She hasn't any friends left sine you started this oil business, and she never sees you.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Do you think the "Enquirer" shouldn't have campaigned against the oil leases?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: You might have made the whole thing less personal!

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: There's no reason why this - this savage personal note -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: The personal note is all there is to it.  It's all there ever is to it.  It's all there every is to anything!  Stupidity in our government, complacency and self-satisfaction and unwillingness to believe that anything done by a certain class of people can be wrong - you can't fight those things impersonally. They're not impersonal crimes against people.  They're being done by actual persons - with actual names and positions and - the right of the American people to own their own country is not an academic issue, Brad, that you debate - and then the judges retire to return a verdict and the winners give a dinner for the losers.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: You almost convince me.  I'm just drunk enough to tell you the truth.  I have to be a little drunk for that because I'm a coward.  You know that.  That's why you keep me around.  You only associate with your inferiors, Charlie.  I guess that's why you ran away from Emily.  Because you can't stand the company of your equals.  You don't like to admit they exist - the other big people in your world are dead. I told you that.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: You talk about the people of the United States as though they belonged to you.  When you find out they don't think they are, you'll lose interest.  You talk about giving them their rights as though you could make a present of liberty. Remember the working man?  You used to defend him quite a good deal. Well, he's turning into something called organized labor and you don't like that at all.  And listen, when your precious underprivileged really get together - that's going to add up to something bigger than - than your privilege and then I don't know what you'll do - sail away to a desert island, probably, and lord it over the monkeys.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Are you finished?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Yes.  Now, will you let me go to Chicago?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're not going to like it in Chicago.  They wind comes howling in from the lake.  And there's practically no opera season at all - and the Lord only knows whether they've ever heard of Lobster Newburg -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: That's all right.  What are you going to do about Emily?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Nothing - if she dosen't love me -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: You want love on your own terms, don't you, Charlie -  Love according to your own rules. And if anything goes wrong and you're hurt - then the game stops, and you've got to be soothed and nursed, no matter what else is happening - and no matter who else is hurt!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It's simpler than that, Brad.  A society girl can't stand the gaff, that's all.  Other things are important to her - social position, what they're saying on the front porches at Southampton, is it going to be embarrassing to meet somebody or the other at dinner -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: She can leave me.  As a matter of fact, I've already left her.  Don't worry, Brad - I'll live.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I know you will.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Hey, Brad!  I've been analyzed an awful lot tonight - let's have another brandy.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You still want to be transferred to the other paper?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Well, you've been getting a pretty low salary here in New York.  It seems to me that the new dramatic critic of our Chicago paper should get what he's worth.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I couldn't possibly live on as little as that, Charlie.  We'll let the salary stay where it is.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Hello, Brad.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Hello, Charlie -  I didn't know we were speaking.

turns.speaker: REILLY
turns.text: Maybe we'd better wait for more word on the President's condition.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What do you mean by that?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: We'll withdraw support completely. Anything else?

turns.speaker: REILLY
turns.text: Mr. Leland sent back that check.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What check?

turns.speaker: REILLY
turns.text: You made it out to him last week after he left for Chicago.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Oh, yes, the bonus.

turns.speaker: REILLY
turns.text: It was for twenty-five thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It does seem too good to be true, doesn't it, Mr. Bernstein?

turns.speaker: REILLY
turns.text: Rogers isn't even pretending.  He isn't just scared anymore.  He's sick.  Frank Norris told me last night he hasn't known Rogers to be that worried in twenty-five years.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I think it's beginning to dawn on Mr. Rogers that I mean what I say. With Mr. Rogers out of the way, Reilly, I think we may really begin to hope for a good government in this state.  Well, Mr. Bernstein?

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: I'll sign those papers -

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: You people seem to forget that I'm the boy's father.

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: It's going to be done exactly the way I've told Mr. Thatcher -

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: If I want to, I can go to court. A father has a right to -

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: Well, let's hope it's all for the best.

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: It is.  Go on, Mr. Thatcher -

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: Mr. Thatcher is going to take you on a trip with him tonight, Charles. You'll be leaving on Number Ten.

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: That's the train with all the lights.

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: You're going to live with Mr. Thatcher from now on, Charlie!  You're going to be rich.  Your Ma figures - that is, er - she and I have decided that this isn't the place for you to grow up in. You'll probably be the richest man in America someday and you ought to -

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: You won't be lonely, Charles...

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: Sorry, Mr. Thatcher!  What the kid needs is a good thrashing!

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: That's what you think, is it, Jim?

turns.speaker: KANE SR.
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Mr. Leland, you were -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: You don't happen to have a cigar, do you?  I've got a young physician - must remember to ask to see his license - the odds are a hundred to one he hasn't got one - who thinks I'm going to stop smoking...  I changed the subject, didn't I?  Dear, dear!  What a disagreeable old man I've become.  You want to know what I think of Charlie Kane?  Well - I suppose he has some private sort of greatness. But he kept it to himself.  He never - gave himself away -  He never gave anything away.  He just - left you a tip.  He had a generous mind.  I don't suppose anybody ever had so many opinions.  That was because he had the power to express them, and Charlie lived on power and the excitement of using it -  But he didn't believe in anything except Charlie Kane.  He never had a conviction in his life.  I guess he died without one -  That must have been pretty unpleasant.  Of course, a lot of us check out with no special conviction about death.  But we do know what we're leaving ... we believe in something.  You're absolutely sure you haven't got a cigar?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Sorry, Mr. Leland.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Never mind -  Bernstein told you about the first days at the office, didn't he?  Well, Charlie was a bad newspaper man even then.  He entertained his readers, but he never told them the truth.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Maybe you could remember something that -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I can remember everything.  That's my curse, young man.  It's the greatest curse that's ever been inflicted on the human race.  Memory -  I was his oldest friend.  As far as I was concerned, he behaved like swine.  Maybe I wasnt' his friend.  If I wasn't, he never had one.  Maybe I was what nowadays you call a stooge -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: It's a letter from her lawyers.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: David, Grobleski & Davis -  My dear Rawlston -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Rawlston is my boss.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Oh, yes.  I know about Mr. Rawlston.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: He knows the first Mrs. Kane socially -  That's the answer we got.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I am in receipt of your favor of yesterday.  I beg you to do me the courtesy of accepting my assurance that Mrs. Whitehall cannot be induced to contribute any more information on the career of Charles Foster Kane. She has authorized me to state on previous occasions that she regards their brief marriage as a distateful episode in her life that she prefers to forget.  With assurances of the highest esteem -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Brief marriage!  Ten years!

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Was he in love?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: He married for love -  That's why he did everything.  That's why he went into politics.  It seems we weren't enough.  He wanted all the voters to love him, too.  All he really wanted out of life was love. That's Charlie's story - it's the story of how he lost it.  You see, he just didn't have any to give.  He loved Charlie Kane, of course, very dearly - and his mother, I guess he always loved her.  As for Emily - well, all I can tell you is Emily's story as she told it to me, which probably isn't fair - there's supposed to be two sides to every story - and I guess there are.  I guess there's more than two sides -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Well, that's about all there is - and I'm getting chills.  Hey, nurse!  Five years ago, he wrote from that place of his down South -  - you know.  Shangri-la?  El Dorado?  Sloppy Joe's?  What's the name of that place?  You know...  All right. Xanadu.  I knew what it was all the time.  You caught on, didn't you?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I guess maybe I'm not as hard to see through as I think.  Anyway, I never even answered his letter. Maybe I should have.  I guess he was pretty lonely down there those last years.  He hadn't finished it when she left him - he never finished it - he never finished anything.  Of course, he built it for her -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: That must have been love.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I don't know.  He was disappointed in the world.  So he built one of his own -  An absolute monarchy -  It was something bigger than an opera house anyway -  Nurse!  Say, I'll tell you one thing you can do for me, young fellow.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: On your way out, stop at a cigar store, will you, and send me up a couple of cigars?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Sure, Mr. Leland.  I'll be glad to.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Hey, Nurse!

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: I want you to stop all this nonsense, Jim.

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: The Bank's decision in all matters concerning his education, his place of residence and similar subjects will be final.

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: I want you to stop all this nonsense, Jim.

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: We will assume full management of the Colorado Lode - of which you, Mrs. Kane, are the sole owner.

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: Where do I sign, Mr. Thatcher?

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: Right here, Mrs. Kane.

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: Charles, my name is Mr. Thatcher -

turns.speaker: MRS. KANE
turns.text: This is Mr. Thatcher, Charles.

turns.speaker: THATCHER
turns.text: How do you do, Charles?

turns.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
turns.text: Yeah, all in crates.

turns.speaker: THIRD NEWSPAPERMAN
turns.text: There's a part of a Scotch castle over there, but we haven't bothered to unwrap it.

turns.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
turns.text: I wonder how they put all those pieces together?

turns.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
turns.text: Anything and everything - he was a regular crow.

turns.speaker: THIRD NEWSPAPERMAN
turns.text: I wonder -  You put all this together - the palaces and the paintings and the toys and everything - what would it spell?

turns.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
turns.text: Or Rosebud?  How about it, Jerry?

turns.speaker: THIRD NEWSPAPERMAN
turns.text: Turn that thing off, will you?  It's driving me nuts!  What's Rosebud?

turns.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
turns.text: Kane's last words, aren't they, Jerry?  That was Jerry's angle, wasn't it, Jerry? Did you ever find out what it means, Jerry?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Yes, and maybe he didn't.

turns.speaker: RAWLSTON
turns.text: Ask the question anyway, Thompson! Build the picture around the question, even if you can't answer it.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I know, but -

turns.speaker: RAWLSTON
turns.text: All we saw on that screen was a big American -

turns.speaker: RAWLSTON
turns.text: Thompson!

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: RAWLSTON
turns.text: Hold this thing up for a week.  Two weeks if you have to...

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: But don't you think if we release it now - he's only been dead four days - it might be better than if -

turns.speaker: RAWLSTON
turns.text: Nothing is ever better than finding out what makes people tick.  Go after the people that knew Kane well.  That manager of his - the little guy, Bernstein, those two wives, all the people who knew him, had worked for him, who loved him, who hated his guts -  I don't mean go through the City Directory, of course -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'll get to it right away, Mr. Rawlston.

turns.speaker: RAWLSTON
turns.text: Good!

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yes, sir - yes, sir, I knew how to handle the old man.  He was kind of queer, but I knew how to handle him.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Queer?

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yeah.  I guess he wasn't very happy those last years - he didn't have much reason to be -

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: That's the whole works, right up to date.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Sentimental fellow, aren't you?

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: Yes and no.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Well, thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: See what I mean?  He was a little gone in the head - the last couple of years, anyway - but I knew how to handle him.  That "Rosebud" - that don't mean anything.  I heard him say it. He just said "Rosebud" and then he dropped that glass ball and it broke on the floor.  He didn't say anything about that, so I knew he was dead - He said all kind of things I couldn't make out.  But I knew how to take care of him.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: You can go on asking questions if you want to.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: We're leaving tonight.  As soon as they're through photographing the stuff -

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: What do you think all that is worth, Mr. Thompson?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Millions - if anybody wants it.

turns.speaker: RAYMOND
turns.text: The banks are out of luck, eh?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Oh, I don't know.  They'll clear all right.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Who told you you could sit down here?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Oh!  I thought maybe we could have a drink together?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Think again!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Why don't you people let me alone? I'm minding my own business.  You mind yours.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: If you'd just let me talk to you for a little while, Miss Alexander. All I want to ask you...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Get out of here!  Get out!  Get out!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: How do you want to handle the whole thing - ask questions?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'd rather you just talked.  Anything that comes into your mind - about yourself and Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You wouldn't want to hear a lot of what comes into my mind about myself and Mr. Charlie Kane.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: How did you meet him?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I had a toothache.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I did a lot of singing after that. I sang for Charlie -  I sang for teachers at a hundred bucks an hour - the teachers got that, I didn't -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: What did you get?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I didn't get a thing.  Just the music lessons.  That's all there was to it.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: He married you, didn't he?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: He was in love with me.  But he never told me so until after it all came out in the papers about us - and he lost the election and that Norton woman divorced him.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: What about that apartment?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: He wanted me to be comfortable - Oh, why should I bother?  You don't believe me, but it's true.  It just happens to be true.  He was really interested in my voice.  What are you smiling for?  What do you think he built that opera house for?  I didn't want it.  I didn't want to sing.  It was his idea - everything was his idea - except my leaving him.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: In case you've never heard of how I lost all my money - and it was plenty, believe me -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: The last ten years have been tough on a lot of people.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: They haven't been tough on me.  I just lost my money.  But when I compare these last ten years with the twenty I spent with him -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I feel kind of sorry for him, all the same -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Don't you think I do?  You say you're going down to Xanadu?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Monday, with some of the boys from the office.  Mr. Rawlston wants the whole place photographed carefully - all that art stuff.  We run a picture magazine, you know -

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I know.  If you're smart, you'll talk to Raymond.  That's the butler. You can learn a lot from him.  He knows where the bodies are buried.

turns.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
turns.text: Right away.  Will you have something, Mr. Thompson?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'll have a highball.

turns.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
turns.text: She's just not talking to anybody from the newspapers, Mr. Thompson.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'm not from a newspaper exactly, I -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: She's plastered, isn't she?

turns.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
turns.text: She'll snap out of it.  Why, until he died, she'd just as soon talk about Mr. Kane as about anybody.  Sooner.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'll come down in a week or so and see her again.  Say, you might be able to help me.  When she used to talk about Kane - did she ever happen to say anything - about Rosebud?

turns.speaker: THE CAPTAIN
turns.text: Rosebud?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Am I sure?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Am I sure about what?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: Do you really want to buy those cigarettes?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Are you serious?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: How long have you been smoking?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: What is this, a poll?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: I'd say you're about nineteen, twenty, am I right?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: What the hell is that?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: That's your lung. By this time, your lung looks like this.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: You're shittin' me.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: You think I'm shitting you...

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: It's a trach ring. It's what they install in your throat when throat cancer takes your voice box. This one came out of a sixty-year-old man.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Unnhh!

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: He smoked until the day he died. Used to put the cigarette in this thing and smoke it that way.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Well, if it's already too late...

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: It's never too late. Give those cigarettes back now, and buy some gum instead.  Here. Chewlies Gum. Try this.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: It's not the same.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: It's cheaper than cigarettes. And it certainly beats this.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Jesus!

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: It's a picture of a cancer-ridden lung. Keep it.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I'll just take the gum.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Pack of cigarettes.  What's that?

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: This? How long have you been smoking?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Thanks. Have a good one.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: Do you mind if I drink this here?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Sure. Go ahead.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Beats me.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: How long have you been a smoker?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Excuse me, but...

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: This is where you're heading. A cruddy lung, smoking through a hole in your throat. Do you really want that?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Fifty-five.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: You've made a wise choice. Keep up the good work.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Maybe you should take that coffee outside.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: No, I think I'll drink it in here, thanks.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: If you're going to drink it in here, I'd appreciate it if you'd not bother the customers.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: Okay. I'm sorry about that.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Hey, now wait a sec...

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: Now he's going to launch into his rap about how he's just doing his job; following orders.  Friends, let me tell you about another bunch of hate mongers that were just following orders: they were called Nazis, and they practically wiped a nation of people from the Earth... just like cigarettes are doing now! Cigarette smoking is the new Holocaust, and those that partake in the practice of smoking or sell the wares that promote it are the Nazis of the nineties! He doesn't care how many people die from it! He smiles as you pay for your cancer sticks and says, "Have a nice day."

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I think you'd better leave now.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: You want me to leave? Why? Because somebody is telling it like it is? Somebody's giving these fine people a wake-up call?!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: You're loitering in here, and causing a disturbance.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: You're the disturbance, pal! And here...  I'm buying some... what's this?... Chewlie's Gum. There. I'm no longer loitering. I'm a customer, a customer engaged in a discussion with other customers.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: That's it, everybody out.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: We're not moving! We have a right, a constitutional right, to assemble and be heard!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Yeah, but not in here.

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: What better place than this? To stamp it out, you gotta start at the source!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Like I'm responsible for all the smokers!

turns.speaker: ACTIVIST
turns.text: The ones in this town, yes! You encourage their growth, their habit. You're the source in this area, and we're going to shut you down for good! For good, cancer-merchant!

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Randal Graves-scourge of the video renter.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Ladies and gentleman, Mrs. Asian Design Major herself: Caitlin Bree!

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You saw that article? God, isn't it awful? My mother sent that in.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: I take it she likes the guy.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You'd think she was marrying him. What are you watching?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Children's programming. What did your mom say when you told her you weren't engaged anymore?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: She said not to come home until graduation.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Wow, you got thrown out? For Dante?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: What can I say? He does weird things to me.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Can I watch?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You can hold me down.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Can I join in?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You might be let down. I'm not a hermaphrodite.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Few are. So what makes you think you can maintain a relationship with Dante this time around?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: A woman's intuition. Something in me says it's time to give the old boy a serious try.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Wow. Hey, I was just about to order some dinner. You eat Chinese, right?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Dick.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: So where is he?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: He went home to change for the big date.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: God, isn't he great?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: No, this is great.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Can I use the bathroom?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: There's no light back there.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Why aren't there any lights?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Well, there are, but for some reason they stop working at five-fourteen every night.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Nobody can figure it out. And the boss doesn't want to pay the electrician to fix it, because the electrician owes money to the video store.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Such a sordid state of affair.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: And I'm caught in the middle-torn between my loyalty for the boss, and my desire to piss with the light on.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'll try to manage.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Hey Caitlin...  Break his heart again this time, and I'll kill you. Nothing personal.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You're very protective of him, Randal. You always have been.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Territoriality. He was mine first.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Awww. That was so cute.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Am I missing something here?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I went back there, and Dante was already waiting for me.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: He was?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: It was so cool. He didn't say a word. He was just... ready, you know?  And we didn't kiss or talk or anything. He just sat there and let me do all the work.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: You dog! I didn't see you go back there.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: I was here the whole time.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You two better quit it.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Nobody! I swear!

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I feel nauseous.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: No, don't!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: When did you get back?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Just now.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: My God. I haven't seen you since...

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Dante. You've got a customer.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I just saw Alyssa's little sister outside. She was with Rick Derris.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Let's not talk about that. How'd you get home?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Train. It took eight hours.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I can't believe you're here.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You're just going to lock the store like that?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I want to talk to you about something, and I don't want to be disturbed.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You saw it?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Very dramatic, I thought.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: It's not what you think.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: What, it's worse? You're pregnant with an Asian design major's child?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'm not pregnant.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Were you going to tell me or just send me an invitation?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I was going to tell you. But then we were getting along so well, I didn't want to mess it up.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: You could've broke it to me gently, you know; at least started by telling me you had a boyfriend. I told you I have a girlfriend.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I know, I'm sorry. But when we started talking... it's like I forgot I had a boyfriend. And then he proposed last month...

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: And you said yes?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Well... kind of, sort of?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Is that what they teach you at that school of yours? Kind of, sort of? Everyone knows about this except me! Do you know how humiliating that is?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I would've told you, and you would have stopped calling, like a baby.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: How do you know that?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Because I know you. You prefer drastic measures to rational ones.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: So you're really getting married?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: No, you're not really getting married?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: The story goes like this: He proposed, and I told him I had to think about it, and he insisted I wear the ring anyway. Then my mother told the paper we were engaged.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: How like her.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Then my mother called me this morning and told me the announcement was in the paper. That's when I hopped the train to come back here, because I knew you'd be a wreck.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Thanks for the vote of confidence.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Was I right?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Wreck is a harsh term. Disturbed is more like it. Mildly disturbed even.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I love a macho façade. It's such a turn-on.  What smells like shoe polish?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: And you came here to what? To comfort me?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: The last thing I needed was for you to think I was hiding something from you.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: But you were.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: No, I wasn't. Not really. I told you'd I'd been seeing other people.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Yeah, but not seriously. Christ, you're ready to walk down the aisle- I'd say that constitutes something more than just seeing somebody.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'm giving him his ring back.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I don't want to marry him. I don't want to get married now. I'm on the verge of graduation. I want to go to grad school after this. And then I want to start a career. I don't want to be a wife first, and then have to worry about when I'm going to fit in all of the other stuff.  I've come way too far and studied too hard to let my education go to waste as a housewife. And I know that's what I'd become. Sang's already signed with a major firm, and he's going to be pulling a huge salary, which would give me no reason to work, and he's so traditional anyway...

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Sang? His name is a past tense?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Stop it. He's a nice guy.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: If he's so nice, why aren't you going to marry him?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I just told you.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: There's more, isn't there?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Why, Mr. Hicks-whatever do you mean?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Tell me I don't have something to do with it.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You don't have anything to do with it.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: You lie.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Look how full of yourself you are.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I just believe in giving credit where credit is due. And I believe that I'm the impetus behind your failure to wed.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: If I'm so nuts about you, then why am I having sex with an Asian design major?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Jesus, you're caustic.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I had to bring you down from that cloud you were floating on. When I say I don't want to get married, I mean just that. I don't want to marry anybody. Not for years.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: So who's asking? I don't want to marry you.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Good. Stay in that frame of mind.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: But can we date?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'm sure Sang and-Veronica?-would like that.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: We could introduce them. They might hit it off.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You're serious. You want to date again.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I would like to be your boyfriend, yes.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: It's just the shock of seeing me after three years. Believe me, you'll get over it.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Give me a bit more credit. I think it's time we got back together, you know. I'm more mature, you're more mature, you're finishing college, I'm already in the job market...

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You work in a market, all right.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Cute. Tell me you wouldn't want to go out again. After all the talking we've been doing.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: The key word here is talk, Dante. I think the idea, the conception of us dating is more idyllic than what actually happens when we date.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: So... what? So we should just make pretend over the phone that we're dating?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I don't know. Maybe we should just see what happens.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Let me take you out tonight.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You mean, on a date?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Yes. A real date. Dinner and a movie.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: The Dante Hicks Dinner and a Movie Date. I think I've been on that one before.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: You have a better suggestion?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: How about the Caitlin Bree Walk on the Boardwalk, Then Get Naked Somewhere Kind of Private Date?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I hear that's a rather popular date.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Jerk. Here I am, throwing myself at you, succumbing to your wily charms, and you call me a slut, in so many words.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: What about Sing?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Sang.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Sang.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: He's not invited.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: He's your fiancé.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I offer you my body and you offer me semantics? He's just a boyfriend, Dante, and in case you haven't gotten the drift of why I came all the way here from Ohio, I'm about to become single again.  And yes-let me placate your ego-you are the inspiration for this bold and momentous decision, for which I'll probably be ostracized at both school and home. You ask me who I choose, I choose you.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: So what are you saying?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You're such an asshole.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I'm just kidding.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I can already tell this isn't going to work.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I'll ask Randal to close up for me when he gets back.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Where'd he go?  I'd have thought he'd be at your side, like an obedient lapdog.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: He went to rent a movie, but he hasn't gotten back yet. Ah, screw it; I'll just lock the store up and leave him a note.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: You're too responsible. But no. I have to go home first. They don't even know I left school. And I should break the disengagement news to my mother, which is going to cause quite a row, considering she loves Sang.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Who doesn't?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Well, me I guess.  So, I shall take my leave of you, but I will return in a little while, at which time-yes-I would love to go for dinner and a movie with you.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: What happened to the walk and the nakedness?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I'm easy, but I'm not that easy.  See you later, handsome.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: How'd you get here so fast?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I left like an hour ago.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Do you always talk weird after you violate women?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Promise me it'll always be like that.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: When you just lie perfectly still and let me do everything.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Um... okay.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: And the fact that there weren't any lights made it so...  God! That was so great!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: It wasn't me.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Yeah, right. Who was it: Randal?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Was it you?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I'm serious.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: We didn't just have sex in the bathroom?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Stop this. This isn't funny.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I'm not kidding. I just got back from outside.

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: This isn't fucking funny, Dante!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I'm not fooling around!  Who went back there?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Are you sure somebody was back there?

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I didn't just fuck myself! Jesus, I'm going to be sick!

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: I can't believe this! I feel faint...

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Call the police.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: There's a strange man in our bathroom, and he just raped Caitlin!

turns.speaker: CAITLIN
turns.text: Oh God...

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I don't know. He just came in and asked to use the bathroom.

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: What time was this?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Um... I don't know.  What time did hockey end?

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: Wait a second? Who was working here today?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Just me.

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: I thought you just said you played hockey and went to a funeral.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: We did.

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: Then who operated the store?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Nobody. It was closed.

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: With this guy locked in?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Everything happened at once. I guess I forgot he was back there.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Was he alive when... Caitlin...

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: No. I place the time of death at about three-twenty.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Well he asked me for it!

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: I can't say for certain until we get him back to the lab, but my guess is he was masturbating, his heart seized and he died. That's when the girl found him.  Something smells like shoe polish.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: What about Caitlin?

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: Shock trauma. She's going to need years of therapy after this. My question is, How did she come to have sex with the dead man?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: She thought it was me.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Are you open?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Pack of cigarettes.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: This is the last time I come to this place.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Using filthy language in front of the customers... you should both get fired.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: We're sorry, ma'am. We got a little carried away.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Well, I don't know if sorry can make up for it. I found your remarks highly offensive.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: If you can just wait a few more minutes.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Fuck that! I'm gonna break my crazy neck on this ladder!

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: What the fuck is this?! I want some service!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: In a second!

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Fuck in a second! This is... Look at you! You can't even pass!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I can pass!

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: How 'bout covering point!? You suck!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Who are you to make assessments?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I'll assess all I want!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Like you're better!

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I can whip your ass.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: That's easy to say from over here.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Give me a stick, pretty boy! I'll knock your fucking teeth out and pass all over your ass.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Are you open?

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: My point is that you're a clerk, paid to do a job. You can't just do anything you want while you're working.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: "Space Alien Revealed as Head of Time Warner; Reports Stock Increase."  They print any kind of shit in these papers.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: They certainly do. Two fifty-five.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I'M GONNA BREAK YOUR FUCKING HEAD! YOU FUCKING JERKOFF!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: Sir! Sir, I'm sorry! He didn't mean it! He was trying to get me.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Well, he missed!

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: I know. I'm sorry. Let me refund your cigarette money, and we'll call it even.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: This is the last time I ever come here.  And if I ever see you again, I'm gonna break your fucking head open!

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Excuse me, do you have...

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: To the back, above the oil.  How long are you staying?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Pack of cigarettes.  Congratulations. I saw that announcement in today's paper.  She's marrying an Asian design major.

turns.speaker: DANTE
turns.text: So I'm told.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: All right, now if you're really feeling dangerous tonight, then Smokey and the Bandit Three is the movie you must rent.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: This doesn't even have Burt Reynolds in it.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Hey, neither did ET; but that was a great movie, right?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Awww, he's so cute. What's his name?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Lenin's Tomb.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: I work in a shitty video store. I want to go to a good video store so I can rent a good movie.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Are you open?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Pack of cigarettes.  Cute cat. What's its name?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Annoying Customer.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Pack of cigarettes.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: What's your point?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: I saw one, one time, that said the world was ending the next week. Then in the next week's paper, they said we were miraculously saved at the zero hour by a Koala-fish mutant bird. Crazy shit.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: So I'm no more responsible for my own decisions while I'm here at work than, say, the Death Squad soldiers in Bosnia?

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Cute cat. What's his name.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Peptic ulcer.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: You open?

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: RANDAL
turns.text: What am I worried about?  He'll probably be glad I started the ball rolling. All he ever did was complain about her anyway. I'm just looking out for his best interests.  I mean, that's what a friend does, am I right? I did him a favor.

turns.speaker: CUSTOMER
turns.text: Oooh! Navy Seals!
